Seville

Visualising Rinconete and Cortadillo's world using Spatial Humanities techniques

Modern-Day Seville


Seville Cathedral

Cathedral at the heart of Seville whose tower is known as 'La Giralda'

Seville Cathedral

Cathedral at the heart of Seville

Plaza del Salvador

Where Rinconete and Cortadillo meet the student, now a square with cafés and bars

SChurch of El Salvador

Located in the Plaza del Salvador

Puerta de Jerez

Where Rinconete and Cortadillo enter Seville, now occupied by a fountain and tramlines

Alcázar

Exterior of the Alcázar Palace, built on the site of an Arab fortress

Alcázar gardens

Magnificent gardens within the Alcázar Palace

Feria de Sevilla

A week-long celebration which takes place around 2 weeks after Semana Santa in April, near Seville's Los Remedios neighbourhood

Feria de Sevilla

The Feria is entered via a huge gate and is made up of hundreds of private 'casetas', or tents

Feria: Flamenco outfits

Women dress in traditional Flamenco dresses

Feria: traditional men's outfits

Men dress in traditional suits, known as the 'traje corto', and a hat called a 'cordobes'. They commonly ride horses

Brotherhoods of Seville

Locals in Seville are commonly members of 'hermandades', or brotherhoods, affiliated with a particular church. La Hermandad de la Macarena (pictured) is one of the biggest and most popular

Semana Santa

During Seville's Holy Week, different brotherhoods carry the relics of their churches in opulent and elaborate processions throughout the city. Pictured: A procession through the Plaza del Salvador

Semana Santa

The members of the brotherhoods taking part in the processions wear traditional hoods and tunics

Typical architecture: interior patios

Houses in Seville tend to be built around an interior patio, like the one Rinconete and Cortadillo enter when they meet Monipodio. This allows the houses the have small exterior windows, to keep out the heat, while still permitting light to enter

Las Setas of Seville

Seville retains much of the essence of Cervantes' time. However, new structures, such as Las Setas (named for its mushroom shape) in La Plaza de la Encarnación, have appeared

Commemorative plaques

Plaques commemorating the places mentioned by Cervantes in his "Novelas ejemplares" can be found throughout Seville

Former Royal Prison of Seville

Located on Calle Sierpes, today a popular shopping street, this branch of Caixabank was a former prison, where Cervantes was imprisoned for "irregularities" during his time as a tax-collector in the city
